image.altText: three men walking while pointing in front of suncorp stadium

props.synopsis: Steven Miles ordered a review into Olympic venues to get better value for money. Now the price tag's the same, but there'll be no world class stadium.

title.children: The $2.7b price tag's the same, but now there'll be no world class stadium for Brisbane's Olympic Games

image.altText: A composite of headshots of both men speaking at microphones.

props.synopsis: Donald Trump uses an appearance on British television to insult Australia's ambassador to the US, Kevin Rudd, suggesting he might not remain in the role if the former president is re-elected.

title.children: Former US president Donald Trump insults ambassador Kevin Rudd, says 'he won't be there long' if he's 'hostile'

image.altText: Emily Breznehan

props.synopsis: With elections looming across the nation, the focus on housing in Tasmania's poll suggests governments are ready to take more radical steps to deal with our housing crisis.

title.children: 'No deposit' home loans, the end of Airbnb and immense rental protections all on the table in an election that could set the scene for other states

image.altText: Fire damage to a cottage style home in Townsville.

props.synopsis: One person has died and three others are in hospital, including a man who attempted a rescue, after a house fire in the Townsville suburb of Hermit Park.

title.children: Police establish crime scene at site of fatal house fire

image.altText: A snake lies coiled on sand in the sun.

props.synopsis: Paramedics have confirmed the death of a 47-year-old man who suffered multiple snake bites in a Townsville suburb.

title.children: Man dies after being bitten by snake in Queensland backyard

image.altText: A smiling blond woman

props.synopsis: Victoria Police is searching bushland south of Ballarat for the body of missing Victorian woman Samantha Murphy.

title.children: Police search area south of Ballarat for body of Samantha Murphy

image.altText: Former PM Kevin Rudd laughs while sitting at a desk

props.synopsis: Meanwhile Wang Yi is meeting with Australia's Foreign Minister Penny Wong in Canberra today, and is the most senior Chinese politician to visit Australia since 2017.  Follow live.

title.children: Government gives one sentence response after Trump's comments on Kevin Rudd

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: 'Kevin Rudd is doing a good job': Government spokesperson
Free Tibet protesters gather on Parliament lawn
Senator Farrell apologises to Senator Cox for 'basket weaver' comment

image.altText: An illustration of a woman on a sofa leans into a robot

props.synopsis: For centuries, human societies have been supercharged by the arrival of disruptive technology so remarkable they changed the trajectory of human history. The next one has already arrived.

title.children: 'The greatest heist of all time': What life will be like when the singularity takes hold

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and Peter Dutton appear in a graphic with religous inconography.

props.synopsis: The opposition says it wants to see the legislation to enshrine new protections for LGBT students and teachers before making any commitment, after the government said it would prefer to abandon the reforms than trigger a fractious debate.

title.children: Liberals say it's 'very difficult' to back unseen religious discrimination laws, as government threatens to ditch LGBT student protections

image.altText: A group photo of Queen Elizabeth and her grandchildren, with circles marking up errors in editing

props.synopsis: The picture, released in April last year, shows the former monarch surrounded by some of her grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

title.children: Another Royal photograph found to have been edited following Princess Kate controversy

image.altText: A crowd of people at a music festival.

props.synopsis: Pill testing is already available in some countries, including New Zealand and parts of Europe. So far, Canberra's Groovin the Moo music festival was the first in Australia to trial it.

title.children: A festival where two people died will be the first in Queensland to introduce pill testing over Easter

image.altText: A blonde woman sits on a ride with a little redheaded boy and a blonde boy

props.synopsis: As sons of the sovereign, Harry and William can't totally escape the media, but the way they deal with this interest in their lives couldn't be more different.

title.children: How Harry and William's shared trauma is driving their very different approaches to a common enemy

image.altText: a man smiling in front of christmas decorations

props.synopsis: John Kirk hates nicotine and tobacco, but the charity group using his photo is telling Australia that vaping saved his life.

title.children: How a Christmas selfie exposed a pro-vaping 'astroturfing' campaign

image.altText: A graphic showing a man clinging to 100 dollar bills with bills flying about

props.synopsis: There has been hope that today's release of the energy regulator's draft benchmark prices will provide relief to people facing skyrocketing power bills. The truth is, that was always optimistic. Here's why power prices are not dropping much — yet.

title.children: New electricity price caps have been drafted and this is what that means for your power bill

image.altText: A woman in a black blazer smiles at the camera in front of a fake 'Tasmanien government' background

props.synopsis: Staff at a media company that produces satirical political videos are warned they could face jail time and a fine over a video that shows Tasmanian Premier Jeremy Rockliff's face, as it could be seen as "advertisement".

title.children: The Juice Media made to censor satirical video showing Tasmanian premier's face

image.altText: A very frail little baby girl

props.synopsis: Watin was a happy and healthy two-year-old before the Israel-Gaza war. Now her mother fears she will starve to death before Gaza receives enough humanitarian aid.

title.children: 'Leaving me little by little': Khouloud is watching her daughter starve to death and can't stop it

image.altText: A gas platform in the Timor Sea.

props.synopsis: A political stoush is erupting over a relatively minor tweak to Australia's environment laws, but opponents fear it could lead to fast-tracking approvals for new gas projects.

title.children: 'Secret gas loophole' or a 'conspiracy theory'? The political fight brewing over gas approvals

image.altText: A close-up of a cane toad standing side-on to the camera, surrounded by blades of grass.

props.synopsis: One of the only cane toad-free places in Queensland has had a close call with the invasive, toxic species, prompting rangers to introduce stricter measures to protect native wildlife.

title.children: Ranger averts disaster after catching stowaway cane toad on a ship heading to a pest-free island

image.altText: An image from above looking down at a boy carrying a blue bucket, walking across cracked dry land.

props.synopsis: The UN agency's annual State of the Global Climate report confirmed it wasn't just the hottest year on record, ocean heat reached its highest level since records began, global mean sea level also reached a record high and Antarctic sea ice reached a record low.

title.children: There's a glimmer of hope after the year that broke every single climate record

image.altText: Image of a customer using a tap-and-go credit card in a store.

props.synopsis: Queensland's peak business group says cash is king for businesses, particularly small ones, and delays for payment can have a dramatic impact on them.

title.children: Calls for tighter deadlines after state government makes small businesses wait for $190 million in late payments

image.altText: Woman with red hair and white fluffy dog pointing at cars on her street

props.synopsis: Councils in Sydney say they can't afford to maintain local roads, which are busier than ever despite the newly opened toll motorways nearby.

title.children: Streets are being 'smashed' as drivers try to save money in the 'most tolled city in the world'

image.altText: A close up of braille dots on a bus stop

props.synopsis: Public transport timetables and updates will soon need to be provided in accessible formats and taxi ranks will be required to increase the ratio of wheelchair accessible taxi spaces.

title.children: Public transport has been 'failing' millions of Australians. It's hoped these new rules could change that

image.altText: A blurred photo of the share trading boards at the Australian stock exchange

props.synopsis: Wall Street is soaring ahead of a decision on rates by the US Federal Reserve while, here in Australia, the ASX is also rising on Wednesday, the day after our central bank left rates on hold. Read it all live on our business and finance blog.

title.children: ASX rises day after RBA leaves interest rates on hold again, while Chinese developer Evergrande is in more hot water

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Why Australians may be celebrating a holiday in Japan
Resources Minister slams 'conspiracy theories' over offshore gas approvals
What is the US Federal Reserve expected to do on rates?

image.altText: Red and silver striped beer keg sits in front of old wooden wine barrels

props.synopsis: Police arrest and charge three people over the theft of beer kegs from Melbourne pubs. Detectives have been investigating keg thefts worth tens of thousands of dollars over recent months.

title.children: Police find 60 beer kegs, arrest three over Melbourne pub thefts

image.altText: A woman in her late 30s in a pink clown costume holding a koala toy in front of a gold glitter backdrop

props.synopsis: Laurie Luxe, Tom Walker and Randa Sayed reflect on the worst things French master clown Philippe Gaulier said to them and why they still chose to stay at clown school.

title.children: These Australian performers survived vicious insults from a French master clown. They'd do it again

image.altText: Two ladies wearing feathered and formal attire sit in a dimly lit room.

props.synopsis: The Museum of Old and New Art (MONA) likes to make a statement – and its 'ladies-only' lounge does just that. But now it's the subject of an anti-discrimination legal fight, brought by a male visitor.

title.children: 'Escaping the patriarchy', or discrimination against men? The legal fight over a ladies-only lounge

image.altText: A woman with short grey hair alongside a man with short grey hair

props.synopsis: The first official meeting between Penny Wong and Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi since 2022 comes at a sensitive time in relations between the two countries.

title.children: Wong set to press China's foreign minister over Yang Hengjun death sentence during high-profile meeting

image.altText: A woman wearing a white shirt and white medical mask flanked by two police women wearing green and hats

props.synopsis: Real estate developer Truong My Lan faces a trial in the economic hub of Ho Chi Minh City accused of leading a scam that caused damages of $30 billion, or about 4.9 per cent of Vietnam's gross domestic product.

title.children: Death penalty sought for alleged mastermind of Vietnam's biggest financial fraud

image.altText: A composite image of Joe Biden and Donald Trump's portraits side by side.

props.synopsis: Not even halfway through the primary season, Joe Biden and Donald Trump have already clinched enough delegates to win their parties' presidential nominations. Here's what still needs to happen before they go head-to-head in a long-anticipated rematch.

title.children: Donald Trump and Joe Biden are now their parties' presumptive nominees. What happens next?

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and a flower garland around his neck holds a microphone and points upwards.

props.synopsis: Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare has defended the "Chinese style" of governing while questioning the values of democracy in a fiery pre-election campaign speech insiders say will create nervousness in Canberra.

title.children: Solomon Islands PM backs China's political system, questions democracy values

image.altText: A keyboard is placed in front of a displayed Facebook logo

props.synopsis: Why are musicians so keen to get played on the radio? It can't be because of the very low sum of money they earn. But there is a lesson for media organisations preparing for Facebook to end the era of paying for news. writes Peter Martin.

title.children: What will happen when Facebook stops paying for news? Here's what happened when radio stopped paying for music

image.altText: an aerial view of an oyster lease at sunset

props.synopsis: A mystery illness is wiping out millions of pacific oysters south-east of Hobart and commercial growers don’t know what's causing it.

title.children: In this sheltered Tasmanian waterway, where oysters are usually thriving, something is very wrong
